title: PSA: K/D/A isn't the only measurement when giving players a champion rank
body: Please stop acting like just because you went 10-0 that you deserve an s-rank.

replies.body: KDA shows your ability to play the champ consistently at a high level. And your CS average shows how well you can lane vs any champs.

Wrong. Support style champions regularly have a lower K/D/A than their carry style champions. Supports and Junglers will generally have significantly lower CS than their laning teammates.

Both of those metrics are worth significantly less than other things such as ward coverage, how you died(in a fight that involved your team, or you alone?), when you and your teammates took objectives, whether you bought items that were strong against the enemy team's champions, etc.

Take all of these metrics, and more, then use them to compare yourself against other people playing the same champion as you, in roughly the same MMR range, and you'll get your rank.

It's SO MUCH MORE than just "I went 10-0, I should have gotten an S rank"
You bring up cs average, but mention nothing about warding?
Aside from certain roles generally having lower KDA due to game mechanics, KDA itself means little in a game where kills don't win games.
I don't think it is because I've had worse kda and even cs as my opponent but gotten higher ranking than them
Exactly. It's not. That's what I'm saying. Too many people are going around crying "I HAD SUCH A GOOD KDA WHY DID I NOT S RANK!"

I'm a little mad, I got an 'A' rank earlier today playing as Viktor.  I went something  like 15/16/(a bunch of assists).

I'm mad because I felt I deserved worse, I clearly had horrible positioning this game and definitely didn't deserve even a B for how many times I died.  I don't want my rank to be based on kills, I want it to be based on...well in this case it would be K/D/A because that's the main purpose of a bursty AOE mage.  I think my CS was pretty sub-par as well.

Dying a lot doesn't necessarily mean you're doing badly. There can be a TON of reasons for why you died. Maybe the enemy WW/Lissandra are focusing you with their ults because you're the biggest threat on the team? Maybe your teammates aren't peeling for you? Maybe some mistakes by another teammate dictate the enemy got baron/dragonx5/huge gold lead, and there wasn't anything you were able to do regarding your deaths. You have no way of telling.
There are always ifs, but at the end of the day every death can be avoided, and very rarely is dying the right call.  Still, 16 deaths is just bad, I didn't deserve an A for it.

There are many times when you dying is the right call, especially when playing against equally or better skilled opponents.

You die, but you're able to get off one last bit of CC for your team to finish off an enemy.
You die, but you're the only one that died and your death meant the enemy wasn't able to smite steal baron.
You die, but you killed 2 carries before doing so.

Those are just 3 random reasons off the top of my head. There's plenty more.
Sure, but do those three come up 16 times in a game?  Maybe.  For one person?  No.  If I had 100 deaths it would be the same argument.
Like I said, those aren't the only 3, just 3 I named off the top of my head. Stop trying to argue for less of a grade lol

I'm arguing for a more fair grading system.  Sure, those aren't the only 3, but again, do you think it was a good idea for me to die 16 times in the game?  I can recall off the top of my head some really stupid deaths.

My point is that I got a very good grade, and for an OK performance at best.
For what YOU judged as an 'ok performance at best'. Seems pretty obvious that you're not the be all end all of grading. Glad you're not working for Riot :)

I don't understand where you're coming from.  Staying alive in order to do damage to the enemy team is the #1 most important reason the AP carry exists in the first place.  Dying is bad, because then you can't do it.  I had a negative score, mediocre CS, and got considered above average by Riot.

Either people are a lot shittier at Viktor than I thought, or it's too generous.

Yea, it's basically 100% based on whether or not you win. I played a Sivir game, had a great cs, great kda, and a shit ton of wards placed. I got an "S" rating. I still only got 47 mastery points on Sivir. I am honestly just ignoring it. It isn't "champion mastery", it is "how many games you've played with this champion".
Actually that's just the champion points going towards your level. The rank you get(S, A, B, C, D) is based on your performance compared to others in the same role.

Yeah KDA doesn't really matter, there are a lot of factors (I assume) that go into the grade you get. I played a game as Corki ADC, I went 0/4/3, and still got a B, which isn't that bad considering my KDA was 0.75. I had decent CS and did the most damage to enemy champions on my team despite having no actual kills. I think it's a lot more in depth than people give credit for. In other games I've had over a 1.0 KDA and got a C because my presence in fights wasn't there as much as my Corki game where I didn't get any kills but I still did the most damage on my team so my presence was still there a little bit.
When I go 10-0-x with 300+ cs as an adc, I damn well better get an A or better.  Anything less is just insulting.

I think that would be relatively suitable for an A. Keep in mind, it's very possible that HOW you got those kills is judged by the grading system. If you're farming an intentional feeder, I'd expect the grade to reflect that.

I feel like the system isn't intelligent enough to tell the difference from a feeder and a person who is just doing terrible. Though I know that some systems like op.gg factor in percentage contributed to kill, theres no way to know if this system does unless its tested.

Uh, it's not hard to take the most common factors present in intentional feeders and apply them to programming.

Where did the person die?
Did they do any damage to any champions nearby them?
Did they die under a turret?
What items do they possess?
Has the person in question been punished before?
Have they received reports regarding feeding in the past?
Have they said any abusive words to their teammates?

Just a bunch off the top of my head.

I've heard that it takes your teammates performances as well. If you go 10/2 but your team's Vayne was 30/0, the system is not as impressed as it would be with you going 10/2 and your Vayne going 0/30
So Master Yi always leaving his team to die and then doing the cleanup is a great play that deserves an S rank?, that's LAME.

Actually I wouldn't be surprised if the system accounts for things like that. It wouldn't be very difficult to judge whether kills/deaths happened while your teammates were alive and nearby(within x units), or dead/nowhere near you.

I'm willing to bet there were other factors involved in this hypothetical S ranked Yi's grade.
yep its lame but how else is a computer going to judge gameplay?  its impossible.  just another silly feature thrown in to excite the kiddies.

Your teamates have nothing to do with the end of game letter rank.

Only mastery points
I went 1/6/24 as jungle Zac and I ended up getting an S rank cause I secured 5 dragons and a baron, and placed easily 20 wards, took towers when my team didn't need me that moment, felt good.

I just went 15/0/6 as MF and only got an A
Went 11/8/20 as Sona support, got an S


Still think the grading is off a bit.

did you not read his post

The fact that you *only* mention KDA is a flaw in the argument. There are so many other factors, it's basically like saying "I chose wheat, therefore my sandwich is the best!" which honestly makes little sense, even if the bread is *really* good.

I carried a game as Maoki Jg. 

http://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/NA1/1820737545/40392809?tab=overview

And only got an A+. :c Lots of invading and Fiora, but that game was fun.
